subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove and today I'd like to talk about the art of dying. As
a person in my seventies, it's something
I think about from time to time. Recently, I took a look at all of the people I have
interviewed since we started the original
Thinking Allowed television series back in
1986 who have passed on.
We have a memoriam page for them on the thinkingallowed.com website.
I'm scrolling through their pictures right now.
There are over fifty people and I've had the great pleasure of having had intimate
conversations with them one-on-one about some of the most important things
they thought about in their lives.
But now they've passed on and there's a sense, even though none of them, to my
awareness, have reached out to contact me since they've gone, there's a sense in which I still have a
feeling of intimacy with them. While they're no longer alive here on planet Earth, I
feel their presence and their vitality still.
The art of dying was, in the Middle Ages, a major topic that people thought about
because, well for one thing, people died very young. For another thing, there were pestilences and plagues.
The church was very strong in Western Europe at that time, so the art of dying had a lot to do with
confessing your sins and becoming
prepared for death in the eyes of the church
itself. But in today's day and age,
we have many other ways of thinking about death and dying. We have for example a large body of research
concerning near-death experiences. Many, many dozens of books and reports in that arena. We have
research with trance mediums. We have people who
endeavor to communicate with the other side using various electronic means. And,
we have research on reincarnation.
As I think about it, it strikes me that
the realm of spirit is
completely open-ended.
That is to say, it can be whatever you want it to be, whatever you think it will be. Perhaps
if you're prepared, you will reach the highest heaven of the highest deity and merge with the divine itself.
Or, perhaps you'll hang around and haunt some familiar location, maybe a bar where you enjoyed
whiskey and cigars. Or, maybe you'll decide to be reincarnated. Or, maybe you will
become a bird and enjoy nature, or visit other planets, or live in the land of 10,000 Buddhas.
The possibilities are almost endless.
But, preparation may be important, because if we die without any preparation for that grand
initiation that awaits us,
what is likely to become of us?
I'm thinking of George Harrison, the musician who died several years ago.
He made it a point towards the end of his life - he was suffering from cancer so he knew he would die -
to die consciously. He wanted to go through the whole process
wide awake and conscious, completely aware of the transition. That's a worthy goal,
I think. It's probably not a goal shared by most people.
I think many people would like to be numb, or asleep, or not aware of
the process, but perhaps
some of you would like to die
consciously. Now, it's interesting in George Harrison's case. He was attacked by a
burglar, someone who broke into his estate and tried to kill him and actually almost
succeeded. He was taken to the hospital with severe injuries. His big regret at the time was - because he had been
traumatized - that he wouldn't be able to die consciously. That accident or injury probably
accelerated his death, but
eventually he died peacefully under hospice
circumstances. His wife Olivia, who was there at the time,
remarked that the room
glowed, it was as if, she said, “If you had been with a camera, you would have seen the light. It was
palpable. It was visible.”
That reminds me a little bit of the death of my close mentor and friend Arthur M. Young, of whom I've spoken
in a previous segment of “In Presence.” When he died,
there was a double rainbow around the sun in the San Francisco Bay area where he lived. In fact,
it was so unusual that it was photographed and
reported in the newspaper. It gave me a sense, having known him personally,
that he had ascended into the heavens. I
have a few other images I want to share with you regarding death. Here, we're looking at a
painting by Maulsby Kimball, former president of the Anthroposophical
Association of America, the organization originally founded by the
Austrian mystic Rudolf Steiner. It's called “Master and Disciples”
and it suggests that on the astral plane - which would be the
hyperspace dimension in which the departed can exist -
that the possibility for spiritual growth and
continuation of individual identity
occurs there, just as it might occur here on Earth. Although, I should think it would be very different on the astral plane.
The philosopher H.H. Price
suggested that being dead, from what he could tell - he was a student of the
spiritualist psychical research literature of the time - he thought it would be like existing in a dream,
maybe a lucid dream, maybe not so lucid, but that
dying is sort of like entering a dream world.
I'd also like to share with you this illustration from the Egyptian Book of the Dead,
where you see the deceased is having his heart weighed.
There's a judgment, in other words, which is common to many, many
traditions around the world, the judgment. In this case, the heart is weighed against a feather. The feather of Ma’at,
or the feather of truth.
If the heart is lighter than a feather, then the deceased gets to enter into the paradise of
Osiris. The Egyptian Book of the Dead contains additional instructions as well about
purifying the heart, about cleansing the soul of guilt from many
sins. And so, confession is also an important part of the
Egyptian tradition. Now, here's an illustration
that was taken from a
Chinese Taoist temple in Taiwan. This illustration is an antique hanging that exists
right outside the doorway of this very studio.
All of my guests here, now that we relocated to
Albuquerque, pass by this
temple hanging as they come in to be interviewed. Once again, you see a judgment and you see
the judge deciding what will be the future for the people who
have been, our deceased. They’re wearing little hats, almost like in Disneyland, Mickey Mouse hats.
The people who were cruel to animals, you'll see, going around, where they have to carry
animals on their shoulders. It's a very common
image, the idea of judgement and
Karma - that whatever you did in your past life, you will have to be accountable for. In
the near-death literature,
there’s quite a bit that's talked about in terms of past life review. In other words, once you’re deceased, your entire life,
moment by moment, instant by instant, in full vividness, passes in front of you. You feel the pain
that other people experience because of your actions
and you feel the pleasure other people experience because of you. In Earth time this can happen all in a few moments, but
actually while you're
experiencing it in the outer body or near-death state, it may seem like a lifetime,
it's so vivid and so real. Time is quite different in
the, I guess you could call it, the realm of Eternity.
So, we have all of these different options to consider,
that I would think - many of you like me are Baby Boomers -
you're beginning to realize that you're at least in the second half of your life at this point.
The idea of preparing for death, to try and die
consciously or
creatively, to make your life as meaningful as possible these
remaining years, is important to you as it is important to me.
So, I'd like to leave you with this thought, “What kind of a death
would you like to have. What kind of life would you like to have
at the moment of your death, when one might say you achieved the
culmination of your life. How would you like your life to culminate?”
I'll leave you with that thought and thank you for being with me.
